fields.customfield_17801: Python 3.13 was supposed to be released on Oct 1. However, a recent announcement says Oct 7. So, we'll probably have to wait until after the written install date for SYS to install it on the machines - though I expect it in October.
fields.customfield_17800: Python 3.13 was supposed to be released on Oct 1. However, a recent announcement says Oct 7. So, we'll probably have to wait until after the written install date for SYS to install it on the machines - though I expect it in October.

worklogs.comment: Find the old epic. List potential files and directories to upgrade in the main repository. Find other potential repositories and inspect them for Python code. Archive unused repositories.
Find a better predecessor epic. Investigate a little bit. Also find an irregularity for the schedule for Python 3.13
Investigate more about the Python 3.9 retirement schedule
Look at DemoDjango repo. Write FHIR-2615 and FHIR-2616.

fields.description:
*What*: Fill in the "retire Python 3.9" epic

*Acceptance Criteria*
* For every piece of Python code, we have tickets in the Retire Python 3.9 epic for
** Moving from 3.9 to 3.11
** Moving from 3.9 or 3.11 to 3.13

*Technical Details*
* Preferably, these are sized according to what migration required last time.
* [The current upgrade schedule in Confluence|https://confluence.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/x/FKJdG] (which accounts for the delayed release of Py 3.13) says that they will have Py 3.13 in DevOps Platform 1 by 21 Oct.
* Epics from "Last time" look to be the HVARD-909 epic, which has nothing in common, and FHIR-1475 - which may.
* *Estimate*: 18h

Python 3.13 was supposed to be released on Oct 1. However, a recent announcement says Oct 7. So, we'll probably have to wait until after the written install date for SYS to install it on the machines - though I expect it in October.
